Situation1: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I stared at my calendar, heart pounding. The final team meeting was about to start—this was the last chance to voice concerns before our department’s new workflow was set in stone. My colleagues expected me to be there, to contribute, to show I cared about the team’s future. But my phone kept buzzing with reminders: it was also the last day of the quarter, and I was still three sales short of my target. Management had made it clear—if we didn’t hit our numbers, there’d be no bonuses, maybe even penalties. My headset sat on the desk, a silent demand to keep dialing, keep pitching, keep selling. I could almost hear my manager’s voice: “Every call counts today.” My stomach twisted as I imagined letting my team down by missing the meeting, or letting my sales team down by missing my quota. I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
